context: [1] One possible, minimally invasive procedure is the analysis of trace gases in the breath of CF patients. [2] Sulfides and other trace gases are known to be produced by bacteria , including P. aeruginosa  and B. cepacia , and the relative amounts of these gases seem to be characteristic of species and strain. [3] For these reasons we hypothesized that sulfides might be elevated in the exhaled breath of CF patients. [4] Here we report the results of a pilot study in which we measured concentrations, in the breath of a sample of CF patients and healthy controls, of three sulfides that are known to be produced by bacteria: carbonyl sulfide (OCS), dimethylsulfide (DMS), and carbon disulfide (CS2). [1] Subjects. [2] Twenty CF patients (mean age, 17 years; range, 8â€“40 years; 8 females) and 23 healthy control subjects (mean age, 20 years; range, 9â€“37 years; 9 females) completed participation in the study. [3] The difference in age between the two groups was not statistically significant.

The study investigates the concentrations of carbonyl sulfide, among other sulfides, in the breath samples of CF patients and healthy controls. However, the specific relationship between sulfanylidenemethanone and carbonyl sulfide is not directly addressed, as they are listed among other compounds without detailed interaction or comparison.
